name: Landscape as character
description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

key_work.title: Landscape as Character
key_work.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. end.title: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert
end.creator_credit: Stephan Elliott, Al Clark, Michael Hamlyn, Latent Image and Specific Films
end.brief_description: When drag queen Anthony (Hugo Weaving) takes his act on the road with fellow cross-dresser Adam (Guy Pearce) and transsexual Bernadette (Terence Stamp). In their colorful bus, Priscilla, the three performers travel across the Australian desert performing for enthusiastic crowds and homophobic locals.

constellations_primary.name: Joy of drag

constellations_other.name: Hiding in plain sight
constellations_other.description: This print of upside-down heads is an early optical illusion featuring hidden characters. Movie studios have continued the tradition of playing with perspective in the bold designs, vivid colours and hidden meanings of film posters.

recommendations.quote: The film's three leads have all swapped fabulous frocks for villainous outfits in superhero films. Terrance Stamp was Zod in Superman 2, Hugo Weaving was Red Skull in Captain America: The First Avenger and Guy Pearce was Aldrich Killian in Iron Man 3.

links.description: The Outback is again a place of prejudice in The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, with the queer crew of the famous bus confronted by small-mind mentalities. But the desert is also a source of hope and freedom, with the characters finding common humanity and community on the road.

links.description: Over 30 years after starring as the young boy in Walkabout, David Dalaithngu again appeared in a film about traversing the Outback. In Rabbit-Proof Fence, Dalaithngu plays Moodoo, an Aboriginal tracker chasing three young Indigenous girls escaping a native settlement to return to their Country.
